Award.AwardTitle: Regio- and enantioselective electrophilic aromatic substitution on drug-like molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Gustafson. Professor Gustafson is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at San Diego State University. He is developing new classes of catalysts for electrophilic aromatic substitution. The goal of this research program is to design new catalysts that allow for the direct functionalization of both simple and complex aromatic molecules, including pharmaceuticals and proteins. Lewis basic groups are capable of activating electrophiles and are readily incorporated into catalyst structures, allowing for modular catalyst design. The project lies at the interface of catalytic, synthetic and physical organic chemistry. Therefore, it is well suited for the education of scientists at all levels. Professor Gustafson's group is well positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science due to San Diego State University's unique and diverse student population. Outreach activities involving underrepresented students at community colleges are part of the project.

Lewis bases can catalytically activate diverse electrophiles towards electrophilic addition reactions. The Gustafson group has recently demonstrated that Lewis bases such as thioureas and phosphine sulfides can catalyze the halogenation or sulfenylation of aromatic feedstocks under very mild conditions. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest this chemistry proceeds through a covalent halenium-catalyst adduct, and that the structure of the catalyst can influence the reaction outcome. The proposed research involves both in-depth mechanistic studies and the development of new catalysts to extend the project to more complex systems. There are three major questions this proposal strives to answer: How do Lewis base catalysts control the regioselectivity of phenol chlorination, and can this selectivity be extended to other classes of arenes? Second, how do Lewis bases conjugated to Bronsted acids catalyze the mild sulfenylation of heterocycles, and can this reaction be extended to peptides, proteins, and natural products? Furthermore, can changes in the Lewis base lead to chemoselectivity towards other classes of arenes? Finally, can chiral Lewis base catalysts be designed to effect enantioselective halogenation and sulfenylation? The educational plan includes outreach to underrepresented students at local community colleges to introduce them to research opportunities available to undergraduates. This outreach activity includes hands-on presentations at local community colleges that introduce students to computational chemistry in the context of the conformational analysis of butane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to obtain new empowering chemical methodologies for the mild and selective functionalization of diverse arene building blocks using Lewis basic catalysts. A key part of this process was obtaining a more detailed understanding of the inner working of Lewis basic catalysts in the context of electrophilic aromatic substitution and related reactions.

Under the category of intellectual merit, the following outcomes were attained.

 (1) The development of an efficient and mild strategy for the incorporation of sulfides into aromatics catalyzed by the combination of Lewis basic selenoethers and Bronsted acids. This chemistry allowed for the incorporation of diverse sulfide moieties into diverse arenes and heterocycles including several FDA approved drugs. Mechanistic investigation revealed that sulfenylations that resulted in electron rich sulfides underwent a competing autocatalytic mechanism, whereas electron poor sulfide products did not, necessitating the use of catalyst. This published work is impactful as there has been increasing interest in Lewis base catalyzed enantioselective sulfenylations, and the recognition of the potential for autocatalysis can help others avoid associated pitfalls. The most impactful aspect of this work is the mild conditions for the incorporation of SCF3 into arenes including complex bioactives. 

(2) The development of a new photocatalytic formation of C–S bonds to form benzothiazoles via an intramolecular cyclization, and sulfenylated indoles via an intermolecular reaction. Mechanistic studies suggest that benzothiazole formation proceeds via an electrophilic sulfur radical, while the indole sulfenylation likely proceeds via thiolate adding into radical cationic indoles. This work is impactful as benzothiazoles are a common scaffold in medicinal chemistry, and the disclosed methodology represents a simple and practical way to access them. The sulfenylation of indoles has been oft-studied, however this work represents an advance as it utilizes unfunctionalized sulfur sources. The described mechanistic studies shed light on how these chemistries proceed, and in the case of the indole sulfenylation suggest a mechanism that is different than that proposed in previous literature examples.

3) We discovered that under our previously reported Lewis base catalyzed electrophilic aromatic  chlorination conditions, phosphine sulfide halogenation catalysts degrade into catalytically less effective ‘pseudo-dimers’, we were able to overcome this by introducing steric bulk at the phosphorous, resulting in catalysts that do not degrade and effect chlorination ~5 times faster. We also discovered that our original ortho-selective thiourea chlorination catalyst degrades into a catalytically inactive guanadiniums under reaction conditions. We overcame this by replacing one of the thioureas with a selenoether, resulting in more stable and more reactive catalysts. Indeed, employing 1% of our best 2nd generation catalyst leads to moderate high conversion with ortho selectivities that are superior to the first generation catalyst (up to ~20:1 o:p) and can be extended to unprotected anilines. This work is impactful, as the acquired insights have led to more effective halogenation catalysts and will guide the future design of Lewis base catalysts. Notably, these next-generation catalysts have formed the basis of ongoing work that have allowed for the regioselective incorporation of diverse electrophiles across several diverse arene scaffolds.  

In the context of broader impacts, this award allowed us to apply the concepts and ideals of ‘organocatalysis’ to offer new solutions to the regioselectivity problem of aromatic C-H functionalization. While chemists have largely focused on enantioselectivity, regioselectivity represents a broader problem throughout synthesis. The catalysts and reactions that were developed with support from this award formed the foundation for future studies that can potentially transform how aromatic fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals and functional materials are synthesized. From a societal and training perspective, this award supported the training of SDSU graduate and undergraduate students, many of them from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds, in synthetic organic chemistry. This award directly supported the training of 4 PhD students and over 10 undergraduates, including 4 who have matriculated to PhD programs in chemistry. In addition to the training impact, this award supported the development of a collaboration with Southwestern community college, wherein a group of SDSU Chemistry faculty and PhD students would give short ‘Ted’ style talks to inform these students on opportunities for them to become engaged in the research endeavor prior to matriculation to their terminal degree university. This collaboration culminated in a ‘Community College’ day at SDSU where the Chemistry department hosted ~25 local students and gave them lab tours, and hosted panel discussions consisting of both faculty and current students that had transferred to SDSU from a community college.
